answers.answer: To be frank, I would just proceed to help her get cleaned up and then resume whatever was going on. I would not devote any special attention or intervention to this behavior. As much as possible it should be ignored (obviously you have to help her get cleaned up).

The evaluation was not for the accidents, but for other concerns/delays in her speech and muscle tone.  The teachers have been trying to ignore the behavior, and it seems to have helped with the time-out, but she has started to urinate during group time and in her chair at lunch.  Could this be a medical issue at all ro do you think it is just behavior?  I knwo my niece started have accidents at age 3 prior to being diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes

You raise a good point, and she should definitely be evaluated medically to be sure everything isOK from that perspective. The doctor might also investigate (if needed) further re: muscle tone because this could indicate some neurological issue.
My child does the same thing kind of. He finds it funny when he does it but says he is not doing it on purpose. I don't know if this is for attetion or a medical issue. What should I do?

question: I have a 2.8 year old child enrolled at my center who has been fully toilet trained for at least 6 months, she has now learned to pee when placed in time out or when on her cot, or anytime she wants attention that is being given to other children.  She is an observer, and does not play with other kids or toys, she usually sits back and watches, so time-out is not a real deterent.  This child also has very low muscle tone and strength in her hands and legs.  I had put in a request for an Birth to 3 evaluation, but she did not show significant enough delays the warrant help.  In 25 years of working with children, I have never had a child that continually does this behavior, and I am not sure what to think or do.  Any advice would be wonderful.
title: 2.8 year old who urinates when put in timeout
